hacking.notes: VERIS 1.3.6: Moved 'Use of backdoor or C2' to 'backdoor' in hacking.vectors causing hacking.variety to be empty.  So adding hacking.variety.Unknown for schema compliance.

external.notes: One of the sources strongly suspects North Korea

asset.notes: We suspect that the dropper Trojan was distributed at the time of the attacks via a compromised patch-management server that pretended to run a legitimate update. Desktop machines had MBRs wiped and ATMs were not functioning.

integrity.notes: installed malware and wiped the MBR

summary: Operation Troy Incident 1: South Korea was hit by a major cyberattack on March 20, 2013, at 2:00 pm local time. This cyberattack caused a significant amount of damage to the affected organizations by wiping the hard drives of tens of thousands of computers. Analysis of this attackknown first as Dark Seoul and now as Operation Troyhas revealed that in addition to the data losses of the MBR wiping, the incident was more than cybervandalism. The attacks on South Korean targets were actually the conclusion of a covert espionage campaign.
